elements.content: Seven new Zn(II) metal−organic frameworks [Zn(tib)2(H2O)](ClO4)2 (1), [Zn4(tib)2(PBDA)3(OH)2]·4H2O (2), [Zn(tib)(HPBDA)]ClO4 (3), [Zn2(tib)(PBDA)Cl2]·2H2O (4), [Zn4(tib)2(PBDA)3Cl2] (5), [Zn2(tib)2(PBDA)](NO3)2·2H2O (6), and [Zn2(tib)(PBDA)I2]·2H2O (7) [tib = 1,3,5-tris(1-imidazolyl)benzene, H2PBDA = p-benzenedicarboxylic acid] have been prepared and characterized by elemental, IR, thermogravimetric and X-ray diffraction analyses. Complexes 1 and 4 are two-dimensional (2D) networks with different topologies, which are further linked together to three-dimensional (3D) frameworks by hydrogen bonds. For 3, partial deprotonated HPBDA− is terminally coordinating to Zn(II) to form a 2D network. Complexes 2, 5, and 7 are 2-fold interpenetrated 3D frameworks, while 6 has a self-penetrating 3D structure. The influences of reaction temperature and counteranion on the structures of the complexes are discussed. The photoluminescence and nonlinear optical properties are investigated.

elements.content: A systematic investigation on the reactions of Zn(II) salts with a rigid tripodal imidazole-containing ligand in the presence of p-benzenedicarboxylic acid was carried out and the effect of the reaction temperature and counteranions on the structure of the complexes is discussed. The solid-state photoluminescence and nonlinear optical properties of the complexes were investigated.

elements.content: Metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) with an entangled structure have been given great attention in recent years owing to their intriguing features and topologies as well as their unique properties. Entangled systems are common in nature and a major theme of supramolecular chemistry. Interpenetrating net is one of the most investigated type of entanglement, which can be described as a series of independent nets that penetrate mutually. In contrast, self-penetrating coordination complexes, wherein the rods (connecting ligands) of the framework penetrate through the shortest internodal circuits, are much rare. Although the prediction and design of interpenetrating and self-penetrating structures are not possible at present since the self-assembly process can be influenced by various factors such as counterions, the coordination number and geometry of central metal ions, the reaction conditions (e.g., solvent and reaction temperature), the larger voids and the lower coordination number of metal centers in the multidimensional MOFs, the more likely interpenetration occurs and the more individual nets interpenetrate each other. In addition, the long rigid and slim ligands may benefit to form large voids, and the resulting complexes may have good tendency for the formation of interpenetrated structures. On the other hand, it has been reported that the Zn(II) has been occasionally used to construct interpenetrating three-dimensional (3D) frameworks since the Zn(II) can have low coordination number of four with tetrahedral coordination geometry. By taking these aspects into account, we focused our attention on the reactions of varied Zn(II) salts with rigid imidazole-containing ligand 1,3,5-tris(1-imidazolyl)benzene (tib) in the presence of p-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2PBDA) as a linear auxiliary ligand to synthesize MOFs. The tib has been previously used in the construction of MOFs with specific structures and topologies as well as interesting properties, demonstrating that tib is a useful ligand in construction of MOFs. In this study, seven new coordination polymers [Zn(tib)2(H2O)](ClO4)2 (1), [Zn4(tib)2(PBDA)3(OH)2]·4H2O (2), [Zn(tib)(HPBDA)]ClO4 (3), [Zn2(tib)(PBDA)Cl2]·2H2O (4), [Zn4(tib)2(PBDA)3Cl2] (5), [Zn2(tib)2(PBDA)](NO3)2·2H2O (6), and [Zn2(tib)(PBDA)I2]·2H2O (7) were successfully synthesized under different hydrothermal conditions and complexes 2, 5, 6, and 7 show entangled structures. The photoluminescence and nonlinear optical properties of the complexes were investigated.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with an entangled structure have been given great attention in recent years owing to their intriguing features and topologies as well as their unique properties. Entangled systems are common in nature and a major theme of supramolecular chemistry. Interpenetrating net is one of the most investigated type of entanglement, which can be described as a series of independent nets that penetrate mutually. In contrast, self-penetrating coordination complexes, wherein the rods (connecting ligands) of the framework penetrate through the shortest internodal circuits, are much rare. Although the prediction and design of interpenetrating and self-penetrating structures are not possible at present since the self-assembly process can be influenced by various factors such as counterions, the coordination number and geometry of central metal ions, the reaction conditions (e.g., solvent and reaction temperature), the larger voids and the lower coordination number of metal centers in the multidimensional MOFs, the more likely interpenetration occurs and the more individual nets interpenetrate each other. In addition, the long rigid and slim ligands may benefit to form large voids, and the resulting complexes may have good tendency for the formation of interpenetrated structures. On the other hand, it has been reported that the Zn(II) has been occasionally used to construct interpenetrating three-dimensional (3D) frameworks since the Zn(II) can have low coordination number of four with tetrahedral coordination geometry. By taking these aspects into account, we focused our attention on the reactions of varied Zn(II) salts with rigid imidazole-containing ligand 1,3,5-tris(1-imidazolyl)benzene (tib) in the presence of p-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2PBDA) as a linear auxiliary ligand to synthesize MOFs. The tib has been previously used in the construction of MOFs with specific structures and topologies as well as interesting properties, demonstrating that tib is a useful ligand in construction of MOFs. In this study, seven new coordination polymers [Zn(tib)2(H2O)](ClO4)2 (1), [Zn4(tib)2(PBDA)3(OH)2]⋅4H2O (2), [Zn(tib)(HPBDA)]ClO4 (3), [Zn2(tib)(PBDA)Cl2]⋅2H2O (4), [Zn4(tib)2(PBDA)3Cl2] (5), [Zn2(tib)2(PBDA)](NO3)2⋅2H2O (6), and [Zn2(tib)(PBDA)I2]⋅2H2O (7) were successfully synthesized under different hydrothermal conditions and complexes 2, 5, 6, and 7 show entangled structures. The photoluminescence and nonlinear optical properties of the complexes were investigated.

elements.content: All commercially available chemicals and solvents are of reagent grade and were used as received without further purification. The tib ligand was synthesized according to the method reported previously. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C Elemental analyzer at the analysis center of Nanjing University. FT-IR spectra were recorded in the range of 400−4000 cm−1 on a Bruker Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out on a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer under nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 from room temperature to 700 °C. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) analyses were performed on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation at room temperature. The second-order nonlinear optical (NLO) intensity was estimated by measuring a powder sample of 80−150 μm diameters in the form of a pellet relative to urea. A pulsed Q-switched Nd:YA Glaser at a wavelength of 1064 nm was used to generate an second- harmonic-generation (SHG) signal from powder samples. The backscattered SHG light was collected by a spherical concave mirror and passed through a filter that transmits only 532 nm radiation. The luminescence spectra for the powdered solid samples were measured at room temperature on an Aminco Bowman Series2 spectrofluorometer with a xenon arc lamp as light source. In the measurements of emission and excitation spectra the pass width is 5 nm. All the measurements were carried out under the same experimental conditions.

Experimental Section

All commercially available chemicals and solvents are of reagent grade and were used as received without further purification. The tib ligand was synthesized according to the method reported previously. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C Elemental analyzer at the analysis center of Nanjing University. FT-IR spectra were recorded in the range of 400-4000 cm-1 on a Bruker Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out on a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer under nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 from room temperature to 700 °C. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) analyses were performed on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation at room temperature. The second-order nonlinear optical (NLO) intensity was estimated by measuring a powder sample of 80-150 μm diameters in the form of a pellet relative to urea. A pulsed Q-switched Nd:YA Glaser at a wavelength of 1064 nm was used to generate an second- harmonic-generation (SHG) signal from powder samples. The backscattered SHG light was collected by a spherical concave mirror and passed through a filter that transmits only 532 nm radiation. The luminescence spectra for the powdered solid samples were measured at room temperature on an Aminco Bowman Series2 spectrofluorometer with a xenon arc lamp as light source. In the measurements of emission and excitation spectra the pass width is 5 nm. All the measurements were carried out under the same experimental conditions.

elements.content: A mixture of tib (27.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2PBDA (16.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), Zn(ClO4)2·6H2O (37.2 mg, 0.1 mmol), and NaOH (8.0 mg, 0.2 mmol) in H2O (10 mL) was sealed in a 16 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and heated at 140 °C for 3 days. After being cooled to room temperature, colorless block crystals were collected by filtration and washed by water and ethanol several times. Yield: about 49% based on the Zn(II). Anal. Calcd for C30H26Cl2N12O9Zn (%): C, 43.16; H, 3.14; N, 20.13. Found: C, 43.10; H, 3.16; N, 20.11. elements.content:
Safety note: Perchlorate salts of metal complex with organic ligands are potentially explosive and should be handled with care.

X-ray Crystallography

The data collection for 1 was carried out on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID imaging plate diffractometer at −73 °C, with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71075 Å). The structure was solved by direct methods with SIR92 and expanded using Fourier techniques. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2. Hydrogen atoms of the ligands tib in the structure were generated geometrically and the hydrogen atoms of water molecules were located directly. All calculations were carried out on SGI workstation using the teXsan crystallographic software package of Molecular Structure Corporation. The crystallographic data for 2−7 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD area-detector diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 20(2) °C using the ω-scan technique. The diffraction data were integrated by using the SAINT program, which were also used for the intensity corrections for the Lorentz and polarization effects. Semiempirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods, and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package. The hydrogen atoms of ligands tib and PBDA2−/HPBDA− in 2−7 were generated geometrically. Hydrogen atoms of hydroxyl groups in 2, -COOH group of HPBDA− in 3 and water molecules in 4 and 6 were located directly. Each O8 and O9 of the free water molecules in 2 were disordered into two positions with site occupancy factors of 0.816(7) and 0.184(7), respectively. Detail of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinements for 1−7 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles for 1−7 are listed in Table . Hydrogen bonding distances and angles for 1−7 are summarized in Table S1. Further details are provided in the .

X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that complex 1 crystallized in tetragonal space group I4̅c2 with flack parameter of −0.02(2) (Table ). The coordination environments around the Zn(II) atoms are shown in Figure a with the atom numbering scheme and both Zn1 and Zn2 atoms locate at the 4-fold axis. Each Zn1 atom is six-coordinated with nearly ideal octahedral coordination geometry by four N1 atoms from four distinct tib ligands with Zn1−N1 bond distance of 2.133(2) Å and two O1 atoms from two terminal coordinated water molecules with a Zn1−O1 bond length of 2.212(3) Å, and the coordination angles around Zn1 are in the range of 89.11(7)−180.0° (Table ). While each Zn2 atom is four-coordinated with tetrahedral coordination geometry by four N3 atoms from four different tib ligands with a Zn2−N3 bond length of 1.975(3) Å, and the N−Zn2−N angles around the Zn2 are from 101.21(16) to 113.76(8)° (Table ). It is interesting to note that one imidazole group with N5 of tib ligand does not participate in the coordination, and thus each tib ligand links two, rather than three, Zn(II) atoms. Namely, the tib ligand in 1 acts as a two-connector, which has also been observed in the previously reported metal-tib coordination complexes. Such coordination modes of tib and Zn1, Zn2 make 1 a two-dimensional (2D) network structure as shown in Figure b. Four Zn(II) (e.g., Zn1, Zn2, Zn1A, Zn2A) and four tib ligands form a 40-membered macrocyclic ring which is further extended by Zn−N coordination bonds to give the 2D net with (4,4) topology. The intermetallic distance of Zn1···Zn2 = Zn1···Zn2A is 10.63 Å. Another point should be noted is no H2PBDA or deprotonated species appeared in 1, although it was added in the reaction.

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of [Zn(tib)2(H2O)](ClO4)2 (1)

X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that complex 1 crystallized in tetragonal space group I4̅c2 with flack parameter of -0.02(2) (Table ). The coordination environments around the Zn(II) atoms are shown in Figure a with the atom numbering scheme and both Zn1 and Zn2 atoms locate at the 4-fold axis. Each Zn1 atom is six-coordinated with nearly ideal octahedral coordination geometry by four N1 atoms from four distinct tib ligands with Zn1-N1 bond distance of 2.133(2) Å and two O1 atoms from two terminal coordinated water molecules with a Zn1-O1 bond length of 2.212(3) Å, and the coordination angles around Zn1 are in the range of 89.11(7)-180.0° (Table ). While each Zn2 atom is four-coordinated with tetrahedral coordination geometry by four N3 atoms from four different tib ligands with a Zn2-N3 bond length of 1.975(3) Å, and the N-Zn2-N angles around the Zn2 are from 101.21(16) to 113.76(8)° (Table ). It is interesting to note that one imidazole group with N5 of tib ligand does not participate in the coordination, and thus each tib ligand links two, rather than three, Zn(II) atoms. Namely, the tib ligand in 1 acts as a two-connector, which has also been observed in the previously reported metal-tib coordination complexes. Such coordination modes of tib and Zn1, Zn2 make 1 a two-dimensional (2D) network structure as shown in Figure b. Four Zn(II) (e.g., Zn1, Zn2, Zn1A, Zn2A) and four tib ligands form a 40-membered macrocyclic ring which is further extended by Zn-N coordination bonds to give the 2D net with (4,4) topology. The intermetallic distance of Zn1⋅⋅⋅Zn2 = Zn1⋅⋅⋅Zn2A is 10.63 Å. Another point should be noted is no H2PBDA or deprotonated species appeared in 1, although it was added in the reaction.

elements.content: When the hydrothermal reaction temperature was raised from 140 to 180 °C, complex 2 with a different composition and structure was obtained. As shown in Figure a, there are two Zn(II) atoms bridged by a hydroxyl group to give a Zn2(OH) subunit. In addition, the asymmetric unit of 2 further contains one and half PBDA2− ligands, a tib ligand, and two free water molecules. In contrast to the Zn(II) atoms with different coordination geometries in 1, two Zn(II) in 2 have the same distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry but different coordination environments (Figure a). Each Zn1 atom is four-coordinated by one nitrogen (N5A) atom from tib ligand with Zn1−N bond distance of 2.005(3) Å and two oxygen (O3A, O5) atoms from two distinct PBDA2- ligands and one μ2-oxygen (O7) atom of hydroxyl group with average Zn1−O bond length of 1.94 Å (Table ), while each Zn2 atom has a N2O2 coordination environment with two nitrogen (N1, N3A) atoms from two different tib ligands with an average Zn2−N bond distance of 2.02 Å and one oxygen (O1) atom from PBDA2− and one μ2-oxygen (O7) atom of hydroxyl group with an average Zn2−O bond length of 1.93 Å (Table ).

In addition, the asymmetric unit of 2 further contains one and half PBDA2- ligands, a tib ligand, and two free water molecules. elements.content: The Zn2(OH) subunits are linked by PBDA2− ligands to generate right- and left-handed helical chains with a pitch of 11.61 Å, which propagate along the b direction (). The right- and left-handed helices are joined together by the other kind of PBDA2− ligands leading to the formation of achiral Zn-PBDA 2D network (Figure b). On the other hand, each tib ligand coordinates with three Zn(II) atoms to form an infinite one-dimensional (1D) Zn-tib chain (). The combination of the Zn-PBDA 2D network and Zn-tib 1D chain via Zn−O and Zn−N coordination yields a 3D framework of 2 as illustrated in Figure c.
elements.clean_text: The Zn2(OH) subunits are linked by PBDA2- ligands to generate right- and left-handed helical chains with a pitch of 11.61 Å, which propagate along the b direction (). The right- and left-handed helices are joined together by the other kind of PBDA2- ligands leading to the formation of achiral Zn-PBDA 2D network (Figure b). On the other hand, each tib ligand coordinates with three Zn(II) atoms to form an infinite one-dimensional (1D) Zn-tib chain (). The combination of the Zn-PBDA 2D network and Zn-tib 1D chain via Zn-O and Zn-N coordination yields a 3D framework of 2 as illustrated in Figure c.

elements.content: To better understand the 3D structure of 2, topological analysis was carried out. The above-mentioned Zn2(OH) subunit can be viewed as a node which is a six-connector since it links three tib and three PBDA2− ligands, and each tib and PBDA2− ligand can be considered as three- and two-connector, respectively. Such connectivity repeats infinitely to give the 3D framework of 2 as schematically shown in Figure d. According to the simplification principle, the resulting structure of 2 is an unprecedented binodal (3,6)-connected net with its Point (Schläfli) symbol of (43)(45·69·8). It is noteworthy that there are open channels with size of ca. 18.82 × 8.73 Å in the single 3D net of 2 along the b direction (Figure c), which allows another identical net to penetrate, namely, the entire structure of 2 is a 2-fold interpenetrated 3D framework (Figure e).

elements.content: When the base was changed from NaOH used in preparation of 1 to tetrabutylammonium hydroxide, complex 3 was isolated. The result of X-ray crystallographic analysis indicates that the H2PBDA is only partial deprotonated in formation of 3 to give HPBDA−, which was also confirmed by IR spectral data of 3 since a vibrational band at 1721 cm−1 was observed (see ). As illustrated in Figure a, each Zn1 atom is tetrahedrally coordinated by three nitrogen (N1, N3A, N5A) atoms from three distinct tib ligands with an average Zn1−N bond length of 2.00 Å and one oxygen (O1) atom from the HPBDA− ligand with Zn−O bond length of 1.930(2) Å (Table ). On the other hand, each tib ligand connects three Zn(II) atoms to form an infinite 2D layer with 4.82 topology (Figure b), which is schematically shown in where the tib ligands are represented by three spokes radiating from the centroid of the benzene ring. There are open channels along the b axis with size of ca. 6.45 × 6.86 Å in the Zn-tib layer (), which are filled by the terminal coordinating HPBDA− ligands from adjacent layers (Figure c). The 2D cationic layers are further linked together by ClO4 − anions through the C−H···O hydrogen bonds to form a 3D architecture (Figure S7 and Table S1, ).

Crystal Structure of [Zn(tib)(HPBDA)]ClO4 (3)

When the base was changed from NaOH used in preparation of 1 to tetrabutylammonium hydroxide, complex 3 was isolated. The result of X-ray crystallographic analysis indicates that the H2PBDA is only partial deprotonated in formation of 3 to give HPBDA-, which was also confirmed by IR spectral data of 3 since a vibrational band at 1721 cm-1 was observed (see ). As illustrated in Figure a, each Zn1 atom is tetrahedrally coordinated by three nitrogen (N1, N3A, N5A) atoms from three distinct tib ligands with an average Zn1-N bond length of 2.00 Å and one oxygen (O1) atom from the HPBDA- ligand with Zn-O bond length of 1.930(2) Å (Table ). On the other hand, each tib ligand connects three Zn(II) atoms to form an infinite 2D layer with 4.82 topology (Figure b), which is schematically shown in  where the tib ligands are represented by three spokes radiating from the centroid of the benzene ring. There are open channels along the b axis with size of ca. 6.45 × 6.86 Å in the Zn-tib layer (), which are filled by the terminal coordinating HPBDA- ligands from adjacent layers (Figure c). The 2D cationic layers are further linked together by ClO4 - anions through the C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds to form a 3D architecture (Figure S7 and Table S1, ).

elements.content: To evaluate the effect of anions on the structure of the Zn(II)-tib-PBDA2− complexes, ZnCl2, instead of Zn(ClO4)2·6H2O for preparation of 1, was used to react with tib and H2PBDA together with NaOH, and a new complex 4 was isolated. X-ray crystallographic data show that 4 crystallizes in triclinic space group P1̅, rather than tetragonal I4̅c2 in 1 (Table ). As shown in Figure a, there are two different Zn(II) atoms in the asymmetric unit of 4. Each Zn1 atom with distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry is four-coordinated by two nitrogen (N1, N5A) atoms of two distinct tib ligands with Zn1−N bond lengths of 1.995(2) and 2.032(2) Å and one oxygen (O2) atom from PBDA2- with Zn1−O bond distance of 1.931(2) Å, and one terminal chloride (Cl1) with Zn1−Cl bond length of 2.2412(10) Å (Table ), while Zn2 with the same tetrahedral coordination geometry, but different donor set is coordinated by one nitrogen (N3) atom from tib and two oxygen (O3A, O4B) atoms from two distinct PBDA2− and one terminal chloride (Cl2). On the other hand, each tib connects three Zn(II) atoms, and two tib ligands and four Zn(II) atoms form a Zn4(tib)2 subunit (), and two PBDA2− ligands also connect four Zn(II) atoms leading to formation of Zn4(PBDA)2 subunit (). The Zn4(tib)2 and Zn4(PBDA)2 subunits interlink together via Zn−N and Zn−O coordination bonds to generate a 2D network (Figure b). If the Zn2(COO)2 unit composed of two Zn2 atoms and two carboxylate groups (Figure b) is regarded as a four-connected node, and each Zn1 by omitting terminal Cl−, tib and PBDA2− are considered as three-, three-, and two-connector, respectively, the 2D network of 4 can be simplified to a trinodal (3, 4)-connected net, and its Point (Schläfli) symbol is (4·62)4(64·102) (Figure c).

Crystal Structure of [Zn2(tib)(PBDA)Cl2]⋅2H2O (4)

To evaluate the effect of anions on the structure of the Zn(II)-tib-PBDA2- complexes, ZnCl2, instead of Zn(ClO4)2⋅6H2O for preparation of 1, was used to react with tib and H2PBDA together with NaOH, and a new complex 4 was isolated. X-ray crystallographic data show that 4 crystallizes in triclinic space group P1̅, rather than tetragonal I4̅c2 in 1 (Table ). As shown in Figure a, there are two different Zn(II) atoms in the asymmetric unit of 4. Each Zn1 atom with distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry is four-coordinated by two nitrogen (N1, N5A) atoms of two distinct tib ligands with Zn1-N bond lengths of 1.995(2) and 2.032(2) Å and one oxygen (O2) atom from PBDA2- with Zn1-O bond distance of 1.931(2) Å, and one terminal chloride (Cl1) with Zn1-Cl bond length of 2.2412(10) Å (Table ), while Zn2 with the same tetrahedral coordination geometry, but different donor set is coordinated by one nitrogen (N3) atom from tib and two oxygen (O3A, O4B) atoms from two distinct PBDA2- and one terminal chloride (Cl2). On the other hand, each tib connects three Zn(II) atoms, and two tib ligands and four Zn(II) atoms form a Zn4(tib)2 subunit (), and two PBDA2- ligands also connect four Zn(II) atoms leading to formation of Zn4(PBDA)2 subunit (). The Zn4(tib)2 and Zn4(PBDA)2 subunits interlink together via Zn-N and Zn-O coordination bonds to generate a 2D network (Figure b). If the Zn2(COO)2 unit composed of two Zn2 atoms and two carboxylate groups (Figure b) is regarded as a four-connected node, and each Zn1 by omitting terminal Cl-, tib and PBDA2- are considered as three-, three-, and two-connector, respectively, the 2D network of 4 can be simplified to a trinodal (3, 4)-connected net, and its Point (Schläfli) symbol is (4⋅62)4(64⋅102) (Figure c).

elements.content: The title complex was prepared in a similar way as that for 4, except that the reaction temperature was raised from 140 to 180 °C. The result of X-ray crystallographic analysis shows that the structure of 5 is completely different from that of 4. In the asymmetric unit, as illustrated in Figure a, both Zn1 and Zn2 with distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry are four-coordinated with NO2Cl and N2O2 coordination environments, respectively, and the bond distances of Zn−N, Zn−O, Zn−Cl as well as the coordination angles around Zn1 and Zn2 are in normal range (Table ). On the other hand, the PBDA2− ligands show two different coordination modes in 5, one as a two-connector to link two Zn(II) atoms and the other one as a four-connector to connect four Zn(II) atoms, and the PBDA2− ligands link the Zn(II) atoms to give an infinite 1D chain as shown in Figure b, while the two tib ligands connected four Zn(II) atoms to generate Zn4(tib)2 subunit, which is same as that in 4 (). The Zn(II)-PBDA2− 1D chains are connected together by the Zn4(tib)2 subunit to form the final 3D framework structure of 5 (Figure c). If the binuclear Zn(II) unit bridged by one carboxylate group of PBDA2− is viewed as a six-connected node, and the tib and PBDA2− are considered as three- and two-connector, respectively, the 3D structure can be simplified as a binodal (3, 6)-connected net with Point (Schläfli) symbol of (42·6)(44·610·8) (Figure d), which has been observed in the structure of Nb2O5.

elements.content: To further investigate the impact of counteranion on the structure of the complex, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and ZnI2 were used in the reaction, instead of Zn(ClO4)2·6H2O or ZnCl2 used for preparation of 1 or 4, and complexes 6 and 7 were obtained, respectively. The crystal structural analysis revealed that 6 crystallizes in orthorhombic space group Pbca, and its asymmetric unit consists of one Zn(II) atom, one tib, half PBDA2−, one nitrate anion, and one free water molecule. Each Zn(II) is tetrahedrally coordinated by three nitrogen (N1A, N3A, N5) from three distinct tib ligands with an average Zn1−N bond distance of 2.02 Å, and one oxygen (O1) atom from the PBDA2− ligand with a Zn1−O bond length of 1.970(2) Å (Figure a and Table ). If the coordination between Zn(II) and PBDA2− is neglected, each tib ligand connects three Zn(II) atoms to form a 3D framework with (10,3)-a topology (Figure b), which has been observed in the previously reported complex [Ag(tib)(PPh3)](CF3SO3). It can be seen clearly from Figure b that there are large voids in the single (10,3)-a 3D framework, and accordingly two such (10,3)-a nets penetrate mutually (Figure c) and are further linked together by PBDA2− ligands to give the final 3D framework of 6 (Figure d). On the basis of the structure described above, 6 has a binodal (3,4)-connected topology with Point (Schläfli) of symbol (103)(106). The framework of 6 clearly results in self-penetration since it is generated by linking of 2-fold interpenetrated (10,3)-a nets, which has not been well reported up to now (Figure d).

It is interesting to note that 7 has similar contents in the asymmetric unit with that in 4 which can be clearly seen from Figures a and a, except that two Cl− anions in 4 are replaced by two I− anions in 7 to coordinate to two Zn(II) atoms with Zn−I bond lengths of 2.5212(10) and 2.6055(10) Å, respectively (Table ); however, 4 and 7 have different framework structures.

elements.content: Each tib ligand in 7 connects three Zn(II) atoms to form helices with R- and L-handedness alternately along the b direction (Figure b) with a pitch of 7.66 Å, while in the case of 4, each tib links three Zn(II) atoms to form the Zn4(tib)2 subunit (). The helices with the same handedness array in an -AAA- sequence along a direction, while the helices with different handedness line in an -ABAB- sequence along the c direction, and all these helices are linked together by Zn4(PBDA)2 subunits to form a 3D framework of 7 (Figure c). There are large open channels with size of 13.26 × 10.25 Å along the b direction, which allow another equivalent 3D framework to fill the voids via mutual interpenetration leading to the formation a 2-fold interpenetrated 3D architecture of 7 (). By using the same simplification style as that used for 4, the 3D architecture of 7 is a interpenetrating trinodal (3,4)-connected net with a Point (Schläfli) symbol of (6·102)4(62·102·122) as schematically shown in Figure d.

elements.content: It is known that multicarboxylate ligands are good candidates for the construction of MOFs with a specific structure and topology due to their varied coordination modes. Therefore, comparison and comprehension of the coordination modes of the carboxylate ligand are a good and efficient process to predesign the MOFs. There are four kinds of coordination modes of PBDA2−/HPBDA− in the complexes 2−7 described above (Scheme ). In 2 and 6, each PBDA2− ligand adopts a μ2-bridging mode using its two carboxylate groups each with μ1-η1:η0 monodentate mode (Scheme a), while in 3, the HPBDA− is a terminal coordination ligand with the carboxylate group in a μ1-η1:η0 monodentate mode (Scheme b). In 4 and 7, the PBDA2− ligand adopts a μ3-bridging mode with one carboxylate group in μ1-η1:η0-monodentate and the other one in μ2-η1:η1-bis-monodentate mode (Scheme c). In the case of 5, the PBDA2− ligands show two different coordination modes. One shows μ2-bridging mode as illustrated in Scheme a, and the other one adopts a μ4-bridging mode with each carboxylate group in μ2-η1:η1-bis-monodentate mode (Scheme d).
elements.clean_text:
Comparison of the Structures

It is known that multicarboxylate ligands are good candidates for the construction of MOFs with a specific structure and topology due to their varied coordination modes. Therefore, comparison and comprehension of the coordination modes of the carboxylate ligand are a good and efficient process to predesign the MOFs. There are four kinds of coordination modes of PBDA2-/HPBDA- in the complexes 2-7 described above (Scheme ). In 2 and 6, each PBDA2- ligand adopts a μ2-bridging mode using its two carboxylate groups each with μ1-η1:η0 monodentate mode (Scheme a), while in 3, the HPBDA- is a terminal coordination ligand with the carboxylate group in a μ1-η1:η0 monodentate mode (Scheme b). In 4 and 7, the PBDA2- ligand adopts a μ3-bridging mode with one carboxylate group in μ1-η1:η0-monodentate and the other one in μ2-η1:η1-bis-monodentate mode (Scheme c). In the case of 5, the PBDA2- ligands show two different coordination modes. One shows μ2-bridging mode as illustrated in Scheme a, and the other one adopts a μ4-bridging mode with each carboxylate group in μ2-η1:η1-bis-monodentate mode (Scheme d).

elements.content: The remarkable difference between 1 and 2 is that the PBDA2− participates in the formation of 3D structure of 2, while in 1 no PBDA2− appeared. In addition, the PBDA2− also contributes to the charge balance; accordingly no ClO4 − anions were found in 2, while in 1 the ClO4 − exists as a counteranion. Another difference between 1 and 2 is that the tib ligand acts as a three-connector in 2, however, only as a two-connector (bridging) in 1. Therefore, complex 2 is a 3D framework with 2-fold interpenetration, while 1 is a 2D network. Furthermore, the notable difference between complexes 4 and 5 is that the PBDA2− ligands connect Zn(II) atoms to form 1D chains, and finally to form the 3D structure in 5, while in the case of 4, only Zn4(PBDA)2 subunits together with Zn4(tib)2 subunits to form the 2D network. Each Zn(II) atom is coordinated by one terminal Cl− in 4, which may prohibit the expansion of a 2D layer into a 3D structure, while the coordination environment of Zn2 is N2O2 from tib and PBDA2− ligands without a terminal Cl− in 5, which may favor the formation of a 3D framework.

Each Zn(II) atom is coordinated by one terminal Cl- in 4, which may prohibit the expansion of a 2D layer into a 3D structure, while the coordination environment of Zn2 is N2O2 from tib and PBDA2- ligands without a terminal Cl- in 5, which may favor the formation of a 3D framework.

elements.content: The structural difference between 1 and 2 as well as 4 and 5 implies the great influence of the hydrothermal reaction temperature. When the reaction temperature was raised from 140 to 180 °C, the dimensionality of the framework varied from 2D in 1 and 4 to 3D in 2 and 5. Furthermore, there are two coordinated water molecules in 1 and two solvent water molecules in 4; however, no coordinated water molecules were detected in 2 and no solvent water molecules were found in 5, which were synthesized at higher temperature. Similar phenomena have been observed in the reported Co(II)-succinate and Mn(II)-BPTCA4− [BPTCA4− = 4,4′-bipyridine-2,2′,6,6′-tetracarboxylate] complexes.

Similar phenomena have been observed in the reported Co(II)-succinate and Mn(II)-BPTCA4- [BPTCA4- = 4,4'-bipyridine-2,2',6,6'-tetracarboxylate] complexes.

elements.content: The notable difference among the structures of 1, 4, 6, and 7 revealed that the nature of the counteranions such as their shape, size, and coordination/hydrogen bonding abilities has a remarkable influence on the structures of the complexes. The perchlorate in 1 and nitrate anions in 6 act as counteranions, and filled in the voids of the 2D layers and 3D framework, respectively, while in the case of 4 and 7, both halides of Cl− and I− coordinate to the metal centers.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out for the synthesized complexes except for 1 and 3 with perchlorate anions, and the results of the TGA are shown in . Complex 2 shows a weight loss of 5.18% before 230 °C corresponding to the release of free water molecules (calcd 5.09%) and further decomposition occurred at 400 °C. For 4, the weight loss was found before 95 °C due to the liberation of free water molecules with a weight loss of 5.26% (calcd 5.31%), and the decomposition of the residue was observed at about 380 °C. No obvious weight loss was observed for 5 until the decomposition of the framework occurred at 350 °C. Complex 6 loses 3.19% of weight in the temperature range of 50−170 °C, which is attributed to the departure of water molecules (calcd 3.57%), and the residue is stable up to 400 °C. For 7, a weight loss of 4.45% was observed in the temperature range of 50−210 °C, which corresponds to the release of water molecules (calcd 4.18%); further weight loss was observed at about 380 °C.

elements.content: The purity of the complexes was confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) measurements and the results are given in . In addition, the diffraction patterns of complexes 2, 6, and 7 after heating showed that the frameworks remain after removal of the water molecules and are stable up to 400 °C for 2, 6, and 380 °C for 7, which are in good agreement with the TG data of the complexes.

elements.content: It is known that only the non-centrosymmetric structure might have a second-order nonlinear optical (NLO) effect. Complex 1 crystallized in an acentric space group I4̅c2 which belongs to polar point group (D 2d ). Approximate estimations were carried out on a pulsed Q-switched Nd: YA Glaser at a wavelength of 1064 nm. The results obtained from a powdered sample in the form of a pellet (Kurtz powder test) were compared with those obtained for urea. The preliminary experimental result revealed that 1 exhibits a modest powder SHG intensity with a response 0.6 times that for urea.
elements.clean_text:
Nonlinear Optical Property of 1 

It is known that only the non-centrosymmetric structure might have a second-order nonlinear optical (NLO) effect. Complex 1 crystallized in an acentric space group I4̅c2 which belongs to polar point group (D 2d ). Approximate estimations were carried out on a pulsed Q-switched Nd: YA Glaser at a wavelength of 1064 nm. The results obtained from a powdered sample in the form of a pellet (Kurtz powder test) were compared with those obtained for urea. The preliminary experimental result revealed that 1 exhibits a modest powder SHG intensity with a response 0.6 times that for urea.

elements.content: The photoluminescence properties of the Zn(II) coordination complexes are well studied, because of its potential applications as fluorescence-emitting materials. Therefore, in the present study, the emission spectra of Zn(II) frameworks 1−7, together with free tib and H2PBDA ligands, were measured in the solid state at room temperature. Intense emission bands were observed at 405 and 390 nm for the free tib and H2PBDA with excitation at 360 nm, respectively, which are same as those reported previously. As shown in Figure , intense bands were observed at 409 nm (λex = 355 nm) for 1, 413 nm (λex = 360 nm) for 2, 416 nm (λex = 358 nm) for 3, 410 nm (λex = 360 nm) for 4, 407 nm (λex = 354 nm) for 5, 410 nm (λex = 350 nm) for 6, 422 nm (λex = 355 nm) for 7, respectively. The emissions of complexes 1 and 4−6 are tentatively assigned to the intraligand transition of tib due to their close similarity, and the ones of 2, 3, and 7 may exist as a mixture characteristics of intraligand and ligand-to-ligand charge transitions (LLCT), since Zn(II) is difficult to oxidize or to reduce due to its d 10 configuration. And the observed small red shift of the emission maximum between the complexes and the ligand was considered to mainly originate from the influence of the coordination of the ligand to the metal atom.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence Properties of the Complexes

The photoluminescence properties of the Zn(II) coordination complexes are well studied, because of its potential applications as fluorescence-emitting materials. Therefore, in the present study, the emission spectra of Zn(II) frameworks 1-7, together with free tib and H2PBDA ligands, were measured in the solid state at room temperature. Intense emission bands were observed at 405 and 390 nm for the free tib and H2PBDA with excitation at 360 nm, respectively, which are same as those reported previously. As shown in Figure , intense bands were observed at 409 nm (λex = 355 nm) for 1, 413 nm (λex = 360 nm) for 2, 416 nm (λex = 358 nm) for 3, 410 nm (λex = 360 nm) for 4, 407 nm (λex = 354 nm) for 5, 410 nm (λex = 350 nm) for 6, 422 nm (λex = 355 nm) for 7, respectively. The emissions of complexes 1 and 4-6 are tentatively assigned to the intraligand transition of tib due to their close similarity, and the ones of 2, 3, and 7 may exist as a mixture characteristics of intraligand and ligand-to-ligand charge transitions (LLCT), since Zn(II) is difficult to oxidize or to reduce due to its d 10 configuration. And the observed small red shift of the emission maximum between the complexes and the ligand was considered to mainly originate from the influence of the coordination of the ligand to the metal atom.

elements.content: Assembly of varied Zn(II) salts with the tripodal rigid imidazole-containing ligand 1,3,5-tris(1-imidazolyl)benzene (tib) and p-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2PBDA) results in the formation of a series of non-interpenetrating, interpenetrating, and self-penetrating coordination polymers. The results showed that the factors such as counteranion and reaction temperature have a remarkable impact on the structure of the complexes in this system. In addition, the linear rigid PBDA2− ligand was further proven to be a good candidate for constructing interpenetrating and self-penetrating architectures, which would provide promising access to the design and synthesis of metal−organic entangled frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Assembly of varied Zn(II) salts with the tripodal rigid imidazole-containing ligand 1,3,5-tris(1-imidazolyl)benzene (tib) and p-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2PBDA) results in the formation of a series of non-interpenetrating, interpenetrating, and self-penetrating coordination polymers. The results showed that the factors such as counteranion and reaction temperature have a remarkable impact on the structure of the complexes in this system. In addition, the linear rigid PBDA2- ligand was further proven to be a good candidate for constructing interpenetrating and self-penetrating architectures, which would provide promising access to the design and synthesis of metal-organic entangled frameworks.

cln_elements.content:
To better understand the 3D structure of 2, topological analysis was carried out. The above-mentioned Zn2(OH) subunit can be viewed as a node which is a six-connector since it links three tib and three PBDA2− ligands, and each tib and PBDA2− ligand can be considered as three- and two-connector, respectively. Such connectivity repeats infinitely to give the 3D framework of 2 as schematically shown in Figure d. According to the simplification principle, the resulting structure of 2 is an unprecedented binodal (3,6)-connected net with its Point (Schläfli) symbol of (43)(45·69·8). It is noteworthy that there are open channels with size of ca. 18.82 × 8.73 Å in the single 3D net of 2 along the b direction (Figure c), which allows another identical net to penetrate, namely, the entire structure of 2 is a 2-fold interpenetrated 3D framework (Figure e).

The most striking feature of complex 5 is the existence of wide open channels with size of ca. 11.57 × 8.82 Å (Figure c), which are filled by another identical framework via mutual interpenetration to generate a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure e).

Thermal Stabilities and XRPD of the Complexes

Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out for the synthesized complexes except for 1 and 3 with perchlorate anions, and the results of the TGA are shown in . Complex 2 shows a weight loss of 5.18% before 230 °C corresponding to the release of free water molecules (calcd 5.09%) and further decomposition occurred at 400 °C. For 4, the weight loss was found before 95 °C due to the liberation of free water molecules with a weight loss of 5.26% (calcd 5.31%), and the decomposition of the residue was observed at about 380 °C. No obvious weight loss was observed for 5 until the decomposition of the framework occurred at 350 °C. Complex 6 loses 3.19% of weight in the temperature range of 50−170 °C, which is attributed to the departure of water molecules (calcd 3.57%), and the residue is stable up to 400 °C. For 7, a weight loss of 4.45% was observed in the temperature range of 50−210 °C, which corresponds to the release of water molecules (calcd 4.18%); further weight loss was observed at about 380 °C.
